message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Understanding the Demographics of Twitter Users
Paper Abstract: Every second, the thoughts and feelings of millions of people across the world are recorded in the form of 140-character tweets using Twitter. However, despite the enormous potential presented by this remarkable data source, we still do not have an understanding of the Twitter population itself: Who are the Twitter users? How representative of the overall population are they? In this paper, we take the first steps towards answering these questions by analyzing data on a set of Twitter users representing over 1% of the U.S. population. We develop techniques that allow us to compare the Twitter population to the U.S. population along three axes (geography, gender, and race/ethnicity), and find that the Twitter population is a highly non-uniform sample of the population.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of social media analysis:

## Definition and Scope

Social media analytics or social media monitoring is the process of gathering and analyzing data from social networks such as Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, or Twitter.(no content)It has been defined as "the art and science of extracting valuable hidden insights from vast amounts of semi-structured and unstructured social media data to enable informed and insightful decision-making."

## Key Steps in Analysis

There are three main steps in analyzing social media: data identification, data analysis, and information interpretation.(no content)Many different types of analysis can be performed with social media data, including analysis of posts, sentiment, sentiment drivers, geography, demographics, etc.

## Types of Analysis

This analysis could be performed as real-time, near real-time, ad hoc exploration and deep analysis, with real-time analysis in social media being an important tool when trying to understand the public's perception of a certain topic as it unfolding.

## Business Applications

It is commonly used by marketers to track online conversations about products and companies.(no content)Monitoring social media allows researchers to find insights into a brand's overall visibility on social media, to measure the impact of campaigns, to identify opportunities for engagement, to assess competitor activity and share of voice, and to detect impending crises, and can also provide valuable information about emerging trends and what consumers and clients think about specific topics, brands or products.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Demographics"

Links: [{"title":"Demography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demography"},{"title":"Demographics of the world - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_the_world"},{"title":"Demographics of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"Demographics of New York City - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_New_York_City"},{"title":"Race and ethnicity in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Demographic statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographic_statistics"},{"title":"Demographic profile - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographic_profile"},{"title":"Category:Demographics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Demographics"},{"title":"List of demographics articles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_demographics_articles"},{"title":"Demographics of India - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_India"}]

## Search Results for "Demographics"

Based on the web search, here's comprehensive information about demographics:

### Definition

Demography is the statistical study of human populations: their size, composition (e.g., ethnic group, age), and how they change through the interplay of fertility (births), mortality (deaths), and migration.

### Scope and Analysis

Demographic analysis examines and measures the dimensions and dynamics of populations; it can cover whole societies or groups defined by criteria such as education, nationality, religion, and ethnicity.(no content)Demographic statistics are measures of the characteristics of, or changes to, a population. Records of births, deaths, marriages, immigration and emigration and a regular census of population provide information that is key to making sound decisions about national policy.

### Applications

Demographic analysis is often used in business plans, to describe the population connected to the geographic location of the business.(no content)A demographic profile is a form of demographic analysis in which information is gathered about a group to better understand the group's composition or behaviors for the purpose of providing more relevant services. In business, a demographic profile is usually used to increase marketing efficiency.

### Global Context

Earth has a human population of over 8.2 billion as of 2025, with an overall population density of 50 people per km². Nearly 60% of the world's population lives in Asia, with more than 2.8 billion in the countries of India and China combined.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Twitter"

Links: [{"title":"Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter"},{"title":"Twitter, Inc. - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter,_Inc."},{"title":"Twitter under Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_under_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"Twitter Files - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_Files"},{"title":"Censorship of Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Censorship_of_Twitter"},{"title":"Stan Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Twitter"},{"title":"History of Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Twitter"},{"title":"Acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquisition_of_Twitter_by_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"2020 Twitter account hijacking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Twitter_account_hijacking"},{"title":"Twitter verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_verification"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Twitter:

## Overview

X, formerly known as Twitter, is an American microblogging and social networking service.(no content)It is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.

## Key Features

Users can share short text messages, images, and videos in short posts.(no content)Posts were initially limited to 140 characters, which was changed to 280 characters in 2017, and the limitation was removed for subscribed accounts in 2023.

## History

Work on the project started in February 2006, and the first Twitter prototype was used as an internal service for Odeo employees before the full version was introduced publicly on July 15, 2006.(no content)The tipping point for Twitter's popularity was the 2007 South by Southwest Interactive conference, during which Twitter usage increased from 20,000 tweets per day to 60,000.

## Recent Ownership Changes

The service is owned by the American company X Corp., which was established following the October 2022 acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk for US$44 billion.(no content)In July 2023, Musk announced that Twitter would be rebranded to "X" and the bird logo would be retired, a process which was completed by May 2024.(no content)In March 2025, X Corp. was acquired by xAI, Musk's artificial intelligence company, in an all-stock transaction valued at $33 billion.

Links: [{"title":"Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter"},{"title":"Twitter, Inc. - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter,_Inc."},{"title":"Twitter under Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_under_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"Twitter Files - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_Files"},{"title":"Censorship of Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Censorship_of_Twitter"},{"title":"Stan Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Twitter"},{"title":"History of Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Twitter"},{"title":"Acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquisition_of_Twitter_by_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"2020 Twitter account hijacking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Twitter_account_hijacking"},{"title":"Twitter verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_verification"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Twitter:

## Overview

X, formerly known as Twitter, is an American microblogging and social networking service.(no content)It is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.

## Key Features

Users can share short text messages, images, and videos in short posts.(no content)Posts were initially limited to 140 characters, which was changed to 280 characters in 2017, and the limitation was removed for subscribed accounts in 2023.

## History

Work on the project started in February 2006, and the first Twitter prototype was used as an internal service for Odeo employees before the full version was introduced publicly on July 15, 2006.(no content)The tipping point for Twitter's popularity was the 2007 South by Southwest Interactive conference, during which Twitter usage increased from 20,000 tweets per day to 60,000.

## Recent Ownership Changes

The service is owned by the American company X Corp., which was established following the October 2022 acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk for US$44 billion.(no content)In July 2023, Musk announced that Twitter would be rebranded to "X" and the bird logo would be retired, a process which was completed by May 2024.(no content)In March 2025, X Corp. was acquired by xAI, Musk's artificial intelligence company, in an all-stock transaction valued at $33 billion.

Web search results for query: "Statistical comparison"

Links: [{"title":"Comparison of statistical packages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_statistical_packages"},{"title":"Multiple comparisons problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_comparisons_problem"},{"title":"Paired difference test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paired_difference_test"},{"title":"List of statistics journals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_statistics_journals"},{"title":"F-test of equality of variances - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-test_of_equality_of_variances"},{"title":"Analysis of variance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analysis_of_variance"},{"title":"Kolmogorov–Smirnov test","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolmogorov–Smirnov_test"},{"title":"A/B testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A/B_testing"},{"title":"Sales comparison approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sales_comparison_approach"},{"title":"Per-comparison error rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Per-comparison_error_rate"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of statistical comparison:

## Key Statistical Comparison Methods

Analysis of variance (ANOVA) is a family of statistical methods used to compare the means of two or more groups by analyzing variance.(no content)ANOVA compares the amount of variation between the group means to the amount of variation within each group, and if the between-group variation is substantially larger than the within-group variation, it suggests that the group means are likely different.

### Paired Comparisons

A paired difference test, better known as a paired comparison, is a type of location test that is used when comparing two sets of paired measurements to assess whether their population means differ.(no content)The paired test is generally used when repeated measurements are made on the same subjects, since it has the correct level regardless of the correlation of the measurements within pairs.

### Distribution Comparison

The Kolmogorov–Smirnov test is a nonparametric test of the equality of continuous, one-dimensional probability distributions and can be used to test whether a sample came from a given reference probability distribution or whether two samples came from the same distribution.

### A/B Testing

A/B testing includes application of statistical hypothesis testing or "two-sample hypothesis testing" and is employed to compare multiple versions of a single variable to determine which of the variants is more effective.

### Multiple Comparisons Concern

As the number of comparisons increases, it becomes more likely that the groups being compared will appear to differ in terms of at least one attribute, and confidence that a result will generalize to independent data should generally be weaker if it is observed as part of an analysis that involves multiple comparisons rather than a single comparison.

Web search results for query: "Geographic information system"

Links: [{"title":"Geographic information system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_information_system"},{"title":"Historical geographic information system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_geographic_information_system"},{"title":"Geographic information system software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_information_system_software"},{"title":"Comparison of geographic information systems software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_geographic_information_systems_software"},{"title":"Talk:Geographic information system software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:List_of_geographic_information_systems_software"},{"title":"Geographic Names Information System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_Names_Information_System"},{"title":"Geographic information systems in geospatial intelligence","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_information_systems_in_geospatial_intelligence"},{"title":"Geographic information science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_information_science"},{"title":"GIS (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GIS_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Category:Applications of geographic information systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Applications_of_geographic_information_systems"}]

## Search Results for "Geographic Information System"

I've found comprehensive information about Geographic Information Systems. Here's a summary of the key findings:

### Definition and Purpose
A geographic information system (GIS) consists of integrated computer hardware and software that store, manage, analyze, edit, output, and visualize geographic data.(no content)Geographic information systems are used in multiple technologies and processes related to engineering, planning, management, transport/logistics, insurance, telecommunications, and business, as well as natural sciences such as forestry, ecology, and Earth science.

### Key Capabilities
GIS provides the ability to relate previously unrelated information, through the use of location as the "key index variable".(no content)Locations and extents found in the Earth's spacetime are recorded through x, y, and z coordinates representing longitude, latitude, and elevation.

### Historical Development
Digital GIS dates to the mid-1960s, when Roger Tomlinson first coined the phrase "geographic information system".(no content)In 1963, the world's first true operational GIS was developed in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, by the federal Department of Forestry and Rural Development, called the Canada Geographic Information System (CGIS) and developed by Roger Tomlinson.

### Applications
GIS and location intelligence applications are at the foundation of location-enabled services, which rely on geographic analysis and visualization.(no content)Geographic information systems have been implemented in a wide variety of domains, including both scientific research and resource management applications.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Ethnicity"

Links: [{"title":"Ethnicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnicity"},{"title":"Race and ethnicity in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Race and ethnicity in the United States census - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_the_United_States_census"},{"title":"Canadian ethnicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_ethnicity"},{"title":"List of lists of contemporary ethnic groups - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_lists_of_contemporary_ethnic_groups"},{"title":"Race and ethnicity in Brazil - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_Brazil"},{"title":"Ethnic origins of people in Canada - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_origins_of_people_in_Canada"},{"title":"Classification of ethnicity in the United Kingdom - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classification_of_ethnicity_in_the_United_Kingdom"},{"title":"Ethnic groups in the Caucasus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_the_Caucasus"},{"title":"List of countries by ethnic and cultural diversity level - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_ethnic_and_cultural_diversity_level"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about ethnicity:

## Definition

An ethnicity or ethnic group is a group of people who identify with each other on the basis of perceived shared attributes that distinguish them from other groups.(no content)Attributes that ethnicities believe to share include language, culture, common sets of ancestry, traditions, society, religion, and more.

## Historical Understanding

The understanding of ethnicity has evolved significantly. Early 20th-century primordialists viewed ethnic groups as real phenomena whose distinct characteristics have endured since the distant past. However, perspectives that developed after the 1960s increasingly viewed ethnic groups as social constructs, with identity assigned by societal rules.

## Ethnicity in Census Data

Different countries classify and measure ethnicity differently. For example, in the United States census, the U.S. Census Bureau and the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) define a set of self-identified categories of race and ethnicity chosen by residents, with which they most closely identify.(no content)Racial categories in the United States represent a social-political construct for the race or races that respondents consider themselves to be and, "generally reflect a social definition of race recognized in this country".

## Global Ethnic Diversity

The world contains tremendous ethnic diversity. The peoples of the Caucasus are a diverse group comprising more than 50 ethnic groups throughout the Caucasus. Similarly, Brazilian society is made up of a confluence of people of Indigenous, Portuguese, and African descent, with other major significant groups including Italians, Spaniards, Germans, Lebanese, and Japanese.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about ethnicity:

## Definition

An ethnicity or ethnic group is a group of people who identify with each other on the basis of perceived shared attributes that distinguish them from other groups.(no content)Attributes that ethnicities believe to share include language, culture, common sets of ancestry, traditions, society, religion, and more.

## Historical Understanding

The understanding of ethnicity has evolved significantly. Early 20th-century primordialists viewed ethnic groups as real phenomena whose distinct characteristics have endured since the distant past. However, perspectives that developed after the 1960s increasingly viewed ethnic groups as social constructs, with identity assigned by societal rules.

## Ethnicity in Census Data

Different countries classify and measure ethnicity differently. For example, in the United States census, the U.S. Census Bureau and the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) define a set of self-identified categories of race and ethnicity chosen by residents, with which they most closely identify.(no content)Racial categories in the United States represent a social-political construct for the race or races that respondents consider themselves to be and, "generally reflect a social definition of race recognized in this country".

## Global Ethnic Diversity

The world contains tremendous ethnic diversity. The peoples of the Caucasus are a diverse group comprising more than 50 ethnic groups throughout the Caucasus. Similarly, Brazilian society is made up of a confluence of people of Indigenous, Portuguese, and African descent, with other major significant groups including Italians, Spaniards, Germans, Lebanese, and Japanese.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Sampling methods statistics"

Links: [{"title":"Sampling (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling_(statistics)"},{"title":"Simple random sample - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_random_sample"},{"title":"Resampling (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resampling_(statistics)"},{"title":"Bootstrapping (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrapping_(statistics)"},{"title":"Design of experiments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design_of_experiments"},{"title":"Category:Sampling techniques - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Sampling_techniques"},{"title":"Sampling error - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling_error"},{"title":"Systematic sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systematic_sampling"},{"title":"Survey sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_sampling"},{"title":"Sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling"}]

Here are the search results for "Sampling methods statistics":

## Overview of Sampling

In statistics, quality assurance, and survey methodology, sampling is the selection of a subset or a statistical sample of individuals from within a statistical population to estimate characteristics of the whole population.(no content)Sampling has lower costs and faster data collection compared to recording data from the entire population, and thus, it can provide insights in cases where it is infeasible to measure an entire population.

## Key Sampling Methods

### Simple Random Sampling
A simple random sample (or SRS) is a subset of individuals chosen from a larger set (a population) in which a subset of individuals are chosen randomly, all with the same probability.(no content)The principle of simple random sampling is that every set with the same number of items has the same probability of being chosen.

### Stratified Sampling
Stratification is the process of dividing members of the population into homogeneous subgroups before sampling, based on auxiliary information about each sample unit.(no content)Utilizing a stratified sampling method can lead to more efficient statistical estimates (provided that strata are selected based upon relevance to the criterion in question, instead of availability of the samples).

### Systematic Sampling
One-dimensional systematic sampling is a statistical method involving the selection of elements from an ordered sampling frame, with the most common form being equal probability sampling (also known as epsem), an equiprobability method.

## Sampling Error

The difference between the sample statistic and population parameter is considered the sampling error.(no content)The likely size of the sampling error can generally be reduced by taking a larger sample.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

6. **Ethnicity** (concept) - One of the three key demographic dimensions analyzed
